awd_titl_txt: A Novel Fuel Cell Catalyst and Support Architecture Based on Edge-site Pyridinic Nitrogen-Doping on Vertically Aligned Conical Carbon Nanofibers
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will explore the effectiveness and working mechanism of a new electrocatalyst design for low-temperature fuel cells.  A pyridinic, nitrogen-doped vertically aligned carbon nanofiber (VACNF) structure is used both as the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalyst and as the support for the noble metal catalyst component.  The hybrid design will potentially increase the effectiveness of the noble metal catalyst, thereby opening the door to ultra-low platinum-based fuel cell catalysts and improving the economic viability of fuel cells for a broad range of energy applications.  

The project is motivated by a recent study, by another group, of the ORR on a model system consisting of well-defined graphitic edges at microgrooves ion-etched in graphite crystals, which suggested that the active ORR sites are carbon atoms next to the pyridinic N formed at these edges.  The present project will advance the current knowledge by focusing on creating a 3-D nanostructured carbon architecture version of the 2-D model system in the form of well-defined nitrogen-doped VACNF arrays that can be implemented in full fuel cells.  Specific technical objectives of the project include (1) understanding and controlling the edge-site pyridinic nitrogen on the sidewall of conically stacked VACNFs as a metal-free catalyst for ORR, the key rate-limiting step in fuel cells; (2) exploring the pyridinic edge-doped VACNFs as highly stable hierarchical catalyst supports for ultra-low Pt loading in both cathodic and anodic reactions; and (3) interfacing the nitrogen-doped VACNF catalyst/support architecture with Nafion ionomer to form a novel membrane electrode assembly (MEA) for integrated fuel cell studies. The unique conically stacked graphitic structure of VACNFs is employed to generate precisely controlled edge-site pyridinic N-doping at the VACNF sidewall, while maintaining the ideal pi-bond conjugation of the internal graphitic layers.  In such VACNF arrays, the open space between the vertically aligned nanofibers allows uniform Pt deposition and effective Nafion ionomer infiltration to form novel interpenetrating bicontinuous MEAs. This will improve mass transport and suppress the flooding issues common in fuel cells. To assist experimental design and optimization, first-principles modeling will be performed to establish the guideline for the physical and chemical behaviors of N-doped VACNF based on the geometric location and configuration of the N dopants, and the interactions with noble metals.  These results will provide critical scientific understanding that will facilitate the development of sustainable catalysts for fuel cell technologies.  In addition to the technical objectives, the project will include a number of educational and outreach components directed primarily at graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students.  The outreach programs will emphasize participation by middle- and high-school girls and will also feature collaboration with Xavier University of Louisiana, a historically black university.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on a unique nanostructured carbon material, i.e., vertically aligned carbon nanofibers (VACNFs), as a model three-dimensionally architectured carbon support. The VACNFs form a brush-like array consisting of conically stacked graphitic microstructures with abundant highly active graphitic edges at the sidewall, which serve both as metal-free catalysts and catalyst supports. Their catalytic properties for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and methanol oxidation reaction (MOR), the key limiting step in hydrogen and direct methanol fuel cells, respectively, are studied by the combination of experimental techniques and theoretical modeling.

The ORR study by rotating disk electrode (RDE) reveals that the 3D VACNF support exhibits an enhanced limiting current density due to deviation from the conventional thin-film catalysts. Ion-beam sputtered platinum (Pt) atoms form strong binding at the open graphitic edges in VACNFs, making Pt nanoparticles more stable than those on amorphous carbon supports. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations elucidate the two-electron and four-electron ORR pathways on the bare VACNF and Pt/VACNF catalysts, respectively. Furthermore, the Pt/VACNF catalysts show an enhanced tolerance to methanol oxidation and a higher ability to recover from carbon monoxide poisoning comparing to the benchmark commercial Pt/C catalysts. These results provide critical insights for developing future high-performance electrocatalyst supports.

Ammonia plasma treatment at elevated temperature of 550-650? C produces higher pyridinic N-doping (3-5 at% vs. ~2.6 at% in pristine VACNFs) that leads to higher ORR catalytic activities. The nitrogen moieties in the N-VACNF gives a strong metal-support interaction and reduces the Pt particle size from 3.1 nm to 2.3 nm. As a result, the Pt/N-VACNF catalyst shows better durability comparing to pristine Pt/VACNF and commercial Pt/C catalysts. DFT calculations validate that the pyridinic N can increase the durability of Pt nanoparticles and the strong metal-support interaction substantially increases the adsorption energy of OH, particularly near the N-doping sites, which helps to compete and remove the adsorbed intermediate species generated during MOR. The PtRu catalysts on N-doped VACNF support exhibits lower CO stripping potentials comparing to the commercial Vulcan carbon support and presents an enhanced electrocatalytic performance and better durability for MOR.

The fact that the oxyphilic VACNF surface and strong metal-support interaction at the graphitic edges are beneficial in suppressing poisoning of adsorbed intermediate carbonacious species is also applicable to similar carbon supports. PtRu catalysts are deposited on N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) which have a similar cup-stacked graphitic structure as the VACNFs. A thin conformal TiO2 coating on the NCNT surface further increases the catalytic activity and durability of PtRu catalysts in MOR, surpassing the commercial PtRu/C catalysts by Johnson Matthey (JM) and Tanaka KiKinzoku (TKK).

Molecular modeling based on DFT calculations provide strong rationales for the observed electrochemical measurements.  Key modeling results include: (a) confirming that the 4e- dissociative pathway is favored on Pt/VACNF under alkaline conditions; (b) finding that pyridinic and graphitic nitrogen elements in the carbon support show different catalytic influence on OH and CO binding (with relevance to both ORR and MOR); (c) showing that graphitic N possesses the electron-donating ability, while the pyridinic N possesses the electron-withdrawing ability. The corresponding charge transfer shifts the d-band level of Pt catalysts, and therefore, affects the binding energies of CO and OH adsorbates; (d) DFT calculations on dual-metal active centers indicate that the ORR reactivities can be depicted in the form of a volcano diagram divided into multiple potential limiting regimes based on a wide range of ΔGOH* values. In addition to OH removal and free molecular O2 protonation as the potential-limiting steps, the protonation of adsorbed O2 and O also emerge as likely potential-limiting steps due to strong O2 adsorptions at certain dual-metal active sites. Among the systems investigated, Fe−Co(OH)s exhibits the highest activity. Moreover, other PGM-free dual-metal sites such as Fe−Fe(OH), Fe−Cu(OH), and Co−Co(OH) also appear to be competitive and would encourage further explorations for Pt-free ORR electrocatalyst alternatives. Finally, reactive molecular dynamics simulations were performed to understand the VACNF support effects on the catalytic performance of the Pt catalysts. The higher percentage of the low-coordination sites play a substantial role in OH binding. Using this insight, we successfully reconciled the molecular modeling results with the measured ORR overpotential for Pt/VACNF.

The close interaction between the experimental group (Li) and theoretical group (Liu) provided strong interdisciplinary training to 2 students who completed their Ph.D. theses on this project and to 3 graduate students who were partially involved. The nanomaterials fabrication, characterization and electrocatalysis applications developed through this project are transformative to broad fields and led to two grants from DOE and NSF. The results have been published in 12 scientific publications and presented at 18 conferences. Strong collaboration with a minority-serving institution (Xavier University at Louisiana) has been established. Over 4 hands-on workshops using fuel cell and solar cell demo kits have been offered to K-12 students to stimulate their interests in STEM.

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2022
Modified by: Jun Li

    The Electrochemical Society

    Wiley-VCH GmbH

    The Electrochemical Society
